NCICB        >                             Infrastructure        >                             caBIO        >                             Technical Resources        >                             Technical Guides        >           caBIO Quick Start     :                                                         News         caCORE 2.0 released     caBIG Pilot Structure     2003 Jamboree Presentations     NCICB Seminars     Publications                          Quick Links         NCICB Support     cancer Biomedical Informatics Grid (caBIG)     Cancer Genome Anatomy Project     Cancer Molecular Analysis Project     Cancer Models Database     Gene Expression Data Portal     caBIO Quick Start     caCORE FTP site     NCI Home                                                                                      caBIO Quick Start                         caBIO Quick Start   caBIO provides its users with three different Application Programming Interfaces (APIs):      Java Interface  via the caBIO.jar file   Web Services Interface  via SOAP   HTTP/XML Interface  via a servlet                  Java Interface [top]         Download  the caBIO_ver2-0.zip file    Unzip the file at the root of your drive (i.e., c:\ or /usr/local/mydrive/)    Read the included  readme.txt       Java classpath setup :   The following jars must be on your classpath to run or compile the code:                     caBIO.jar      http://ncicb.nci.nih.gov/core/caBIO              xercesImpl.jar      http://xml.apache.org/xerces-j/              xml-apis.jar      http://xml.apache.org/xalan-j/              jaxb-rt-1.0-ea.jar      http://java.sun.com/xml/jaxb/                Example classpath to run GeneDemo:    Windows:     java -classpath .\JavaDemos;.\jars\caBIO.jar;.\jars\xercesImpl.jar;.\jars\xml-apis.jar;.\jars\jaxb-rt-1.0-ea.jar; -Djava.security.policy=java.policy GeneDemo       Unix:     java -classpath ./JavaDemos:./jars/caBIO.jar:./jars/xercesImpl.jar:./jars/xml-apis.jar:./jars/jaxb-rt-1.0-ea.jar: -Djava.security.policy=java.policy GeneDemo         These jar files are included in the distribution and are located in the jars directory. The caBIO.jar is configured to point at the public caBIO server.          RMI Configuration :   The caBIO.jar communicates to the caBIO server located at NCICB via Java's Remote Invocation Method (RMI) protocol. The jar file is already configured to connect to the caBIO server using a fixed port RMI custom socket factory.            Server Address    Ports          cabio-server.nci.nih.gov     8080 (RMI registration port)           8443 (RMI Data Port)         You can learn more about Java RMI at  RMI and Object Serialization FAQ            Java Security Policy File :   A Java security policy is also required to make calls against the caBIO server          because of the RMI protocol used by the caBIO.jar. A default java.policy file          is included in the distribution. The policies defined in this java.policy file         are for the protection of your system and NOT the caBIO server.  Therefore, you         are free (and encouraged) to edit the included java.policy file as appropriate for          your system. For more information, see:           http://java.sun.com/security/          Example Demo files :   To verify proper installation and communication to the caBIO server, you can run one of the following Java example files included in the distribution:          GeneDemo.java          EVSDemo.java                    OntologyDemo.java          CaseReportFormDemo.java          CancerModelDemo.java         The Java examples source code as well as compiled byte code have been included as part of the distribution along with batch/shell scripts that will correctly set up the classpath.                Executing the Examples :   To run an example, type the following at the command prompt:                      run_caBIO.bat [name]  (Windows)    or          sh run_caBIO.sh [name]  (Unix)               For example, to run the GeneDemo on Windows, type the following at the command prompt:                      run_caBIO.bat GeneDemo            To run the GeneDemo on Unix, type the following at the command prompt:                      sh run_caBIO.sh GeneDemo                     Recompile the examples   If you would like to recompile an example, you can use the compile_caBIO scripts or Ant.              compile_caBIO         To use the compile_caBIO script, type the following at the command prompt:                  compile_caBIO.bat JavaDemos/[name].java        For example, if you would like to recompile GeneDemo.java on Windows, type the following at the command prompt:                      compile_caBIO.bat JavaDemos/GeneDemo.java            On Unix, type the following at the command prompt:                      sh compile_caBIO.sh JavaDemos/GeneDemo.java              Ant         Ant is an open source compile tool available at:  http://ant.apache.org/ .     Refer to the installation directions included with the Ant distribution. After you have installed Ant,      change to the build directory and type:                      ant                                Web Services Interface [top]      The caBIO project provides a SOAP interface for non-Java applications. In this model the client issues XML-encoded requests specifying the desired data services to the appropriate caBIO host address and port and, in exchange, receives XML-encoded responses.      Install a SOAP client package :    SOAP client package handles the implementation of the envelope and the resolution          of the SOAP types.  A number of SOAP packages catering to different programming          languages are available at  http://www.w3.org/TR/SOAP/           and at  Soapware .   The PERL examples included in the distribution utilize SOAP::LITE for Perl, which can be freely downloaded from the  http://www.soaplite.com/  or  ActiveState  web site .          Accessing the caBIO SOAP Services :   The following link points to the list of caBIO SOAP services provided by the NCICB server:    http://cabio.nci.nih.gov/soap/services/index.html            caBIO SOAP Configuration :              server:        cabio.nci.nih.gov              Listening Port:        80              URI        such as 'urn:nci-gene-service', See  caBIO SOAP Services              Method        such as 'getGenes',  See  caBIO SOAP Services                 Executing the Examples :    To run the geneClient.pl example, type the following at the command prompt from the /PerlSOAP folder:                      geneClient.pl cabio.nci.nih.gov 80 getGenes -symbol brca1                                         HTTP/XML Interface [top]    For example, to query for Genes where the Gene name is "BRCA1"                   http://cabio.nci.nih.gov/servlet/GetXML?query=Gene&crit_name=BRCA1      To query for Chromosome information where Gene name is "BRCA1"                   http://cabio.nci.nih.gov/servlet/GetXML?query=Chromosome&crit_genes_name=BRCA1         In this case the association role from Chromosome to Gene is called "genes"      To further refine the query for only human chromosomes where Gene name is "BRCA1"                   http://cabio.nci.nih.gov/servlet/GetXML?query=Chromosome&crit_genes_name=BRCA1&crit_taxon_commonName=Human       In this case the association role from Chromosome and Gene is called "genes" and the association role from Chromosome and Taxon is called "taxon".   And "name" is an attribute of both "genes" and "taxon".      In another example, we can simply formulate the query to return Gene information for Targets which have an association to Agents named "ADENO-P53" or just "ADENO*".                  http://cabio.nci.nih.gov/servlet/GetXML?query=Gene&crit_targets_agents_name=ADENO*                                                                   Please send comments and suggestions to  ncicb@pop.nci.nih.gov     |  Privacy Notice  |  Accessibility Information

This means that the framework no longer validates the options, it just checks for things that it understands, leaving the others.  This means that typing errors could cause confusion. Converted all the GNUmakefiles, including the Required.mk fragment to SRT2 - including use of the binary building rules.  Converted Required.mk into RequiredPre.mk (before standard.mk) and RequiredPost.mk (after standard.mk).  Since the SRT bin rules are not working properly, I put a hack into the post makefile that corrects the problem, this will need to be removed when SRT is fixed. Removed all the code that made use of JTC or ACE.  The framework now uses mutexes (Locks) directly from pthreads if the --thread_safe option is given.  Removed the threading from JTC and ACE from the framework.  I provide a simple way to use pthreads for testing purposes. Cleaned up all the examples so they are built during the tbin phase. Removed any dependence on d0om or EDM that they had. The "-mem" option now reports the sizes in MB instead of pages. Added queryAlias() functions to the already-large set of functions to query information out of the DataStore. Created a public class called CmdLineOptions to be used as follows: #include "framework/CmdLineOptions.hpp" ... void func() { CmdLineOptions opts; cout << opts.getArgc() << " = number of args" << endl; char** argv = opts.getArgv(); cout << argv[0] << " = program name" << endl; } Added a switch called -badExceptionHandlingMode that forces the framework not to catch std::exception or XRCP excpetions.  This was provided because David Adams wanted to get a core dump that contained a stack trace when an exception is thrown and Herb seconded that request.  The framework will produce a core file if this switch is on and any user code throws an std::exception or causes one to be thrown by the standard library.  The same is try of RCP - no information will be printed because the exceptions are not caught by the framework. The framework only knowns about std::exceptions, RCP exceptions, and framework exception classes, all others cause a core dump now. ( catch(...) is removed ) Reorganized a few of the procedures near the main routine to make handling of the exception processing switch easier. Fixed a problem in the "current context" handle.  This needs to be set to nothing before the Framework class destroys the main Controller (Dispatcher) or messages logged in the destrctors of packages can cause core dumps depending on the order in which they are destructed. Updated the simple example to run using the new exception switch. Changed the framework exceptions to be easier to understand and use.  (There is a lot more work to be done here - this is just a small cleanup).  Converted the framework code to use the newer framework exception classes. iframework: 04/25/2000 v00-00-07: Converted to SRT2 for binary targets. Converted to use new threading and option processing in the framework.|MISSING|2000-05-08 06:48:01|2000-05-08 13:26:40|2000-05-08 18:58:20||next test build|next test build|t89 and nt89  454  jbk@fnal.gov|iframework|v00-00-07|Framework: 04/18/00 v00-06-40: Changed option processing to make argc,argv available to user. This means that the framework no longer validates the options, it just checks for things that it understands, leaving the others.  This means that typing errors could cause confusion. Converted all the GNUmakefiles, including the Required.mk fragment to SRT2 - including use of the binary building rules.  Converted Required.mk into RequiredPre.mk (before standard.mk) and RequiredPost.mk (after standard.mk).  Since the SRT bin rules are not working properly, I put a hack into the post makefile that corrects the problem, this will need to be removed when SRT is fixed. Removed all the code that made use of JTC or ACE.  The framework now uses mutexes (Locks) directly from pthreads if the --thread_safe option is given.  Removed the threading from JTC and ACE from the framework.  I provide a simple way to use pthreads for testing purposes. Cleaned up all the examples so they are built during the tbin phase. Removed any dependence on d0om or EDM that they had. The "-mem" option now reports the sizes in MB instead of pages. Added queryAlias() functions to the already-large set of functions to query information out of the DataStore. Created a public class called CmdLineOptions to be used as follows: #include "framework/CmdLineOptions.hpp" ... void func() { CmdLineOptions opts; cout << opts.getArgc() << " = number of args" << endl; char** argv = opts.getArgv(); cout << argv[0] << " = program name" << endl; } Added a switch called -badExceptionHandlingMode that forces the framework not to catch std::exception or XRCP excpetions.  This was provided because David Adams wanted to get a core dump that contained a stack trace when an exception is thrown and Herb seconded that request.  The framework will produce a core file if this switch is on and any user code throws an std::exception or causes one to be thrown by the standard library.  The same is try of RCP - no information will be printed because the exceptions are not caught by the framework. The framework only knowns about std::exceptions, RCP exceptions, and framework exception classes, all others cause a core dump now. ( catch(...) is removed ) Reorganized a few of the procedures near the main routine to make handling of the exception processing switch easier. Fixed a problem in the "current context" handle.  This needs to be set to nothing before the Framework class destroys the main Controller (Dispatcher) or messages logged in the destrctors of packages can cause core dumps depending on the order in which they are destructed. Updated the simple example to run using the new exception switch. Changed the framework exceptions to be easier to understand and use.  (There is a lot more work to be done here - this is just a small cleanup).  Converted the framework code to use the newer framework exception classes. iframework: 04/25/2000 v00-00-07: Converted to SRT2 for binary targets. Converted to use new threading and option processing in the framework.|MISSING|2000-05-08 06:48:01|2000-05-08 13:26:40|2000-05-08 18:58:20||next test build|next test build|t89 and nt89  473  jbk@fnal.gov|iframework|v00-00-07|Framework: 04/18/00 v00-06-40: Changed option processing to make argc,argv available to user. D0 CVS Repository Browser        This is a WWW interface for CVS Repositories.  You can browse the file hierarchy by picking directories  (which have slashes after them,  e.g. ,  src/ ).  If you pick a file, you will see the revision history  for that file.  Selecting a revision number will download that revision of  the file.  There is a link at each revision to display  diffs between that revision and the previous one, and  a form at the bottom of the page that allows you to  display diffs between arbitrary revisions.        This script  ( ViewCVS )  has been written by Greg Stein  < gstein@lyra.org >  based on the   cvsweb   script by Henner Zeller  < zeller@think.de >;  it is covered by the   BSD  Licence .  If you would like to use this CGI script on your own web server and  CVS tree, see Greg's   ViewCVS distribution  site .  Please send any suggestions, comments, etc. to   Greg Stein .        This script has been adapted for use in D0: see the   README.Dzero   file for the details of the installation. Look at the  package browser  for code changes.     Color code :  HEAD version , p14 version , p15 version  of code.           History of the cal_t42 package              jan 2003 : the package is create locally on d0-LPNHE area for develloping and preliminary studies         feb 2003 : algorithm shows good results, preparing for an official package         25 feb 2003 : the package folder has been created empty awaiting for a first bug free release         5 mar 2003 : the package structure is set and files are first commited to repository   the version is tagged v00-00-00 as the first release.              6 mar 2003 : the map of rejected cell plot is added and the rcp is set as shadow mode for d0reco          12 mar 2003 : error log added for file not found errors, the script of STRUCTURE.dat is set. This is the pre-version to d0reco   CODEGEN, script and STRUCTURE.file -> STRUCTURE.dat changes, this is the final version to d0reco tagged with v00-00-01         19 mar 2003 : methods to access full and clean list of cell are added, a minor memory leak is repared (due to CalCell objects ), the plots are now energy/sigma. code is tagged v00-00-02. It is also tagged as p14-br by mistak, repaired by alan.  Then, the p14 branch is created with this version of code                 25 mar 2003 : version p14-br-01 with the minor memory meak fixed          1 apr 2003 : There is a problem with the exception thrower header which is not included. #include "ZMthrow.h" added, version p14-br-02   and versoin v00-00-03 .  Release request for p15 next test build         10 apri 2003 : the recombining algorithm is added. the histogram range are modified. the use of ReadChannel is made obsolete and method readchannel() is deleted, channeltable is suppressed. the population count is put in the parameters list of the calt42chunk. the noise value for a channel with no pedestal RMS in the officla file is sqearch in phi neighbour or set to the mean value in the region if no correct neighbour. the version is tagged v00-00-04     but the rcp of combine is not present and added after tagging !         17 apr 2003 : the first threshold value is raised to 2.5 ( 0.0 before) not version tag         22 apr 2003 : HEAD version is tagged v00-00-05 and I mess up with some tags (sorry)          24 june 2003 : the neighbourhood standalone algorithms are put in CVS.          3 oct 2003 :  The code of p14 is updated with some minor corrections brought to head version, recombination hook and a killing rcp for top_analyze purpose Same thing done except for the killing rcp for p15 code              vlimant      Last modified: Fri Oct  3 11:59:35 CDT 2003
